_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE 



This facility complies with ANSI/CGA G-2.1-2014 requirements with amendments for Anhydrous Ammonia storage.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the local fire department (via a 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the fire department notification, the appropriate LEPC/EMA will be contacted.



While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned. In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned.  In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.  



The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or Acts of God which might occur on our premises.  The primary emergency coordinator for the facility is the location manager. 





DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT THE FACILITY



This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant.  The anhydrous ammonia, stored at this facility, is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes. The system consists of storage vessel(s) with associated piping, valves, liquid pump(s), and other miscellaneous equipment.  From time-to-time throughout the year, portable nurse tanks may also be present at this site. The anhydrous ammonia plant is operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and F

all).  Full-time equivalent employee numbers were computed on that basis. The plant operates a total of three months (1/4 of the year).  The FTEs for the facility is two (2).





GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI/CGA G-2.1-2014 with amendments and State law.



In addition, the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia.  The company has extended to the responding fire department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant, to participate in mock emergency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company. 





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



This facility experienced an injury to an employee during maintenance repair work on March 7, 2016 at/or around 12:45 PM.  Employee was performing maintenance on anhydrous ammonia pump on a bulk storage facility.  Employee was wearing the proper personal protective equipment along with long trousers and closed toe footwear.  Employee began by following protocol to open valves slowly and after bleeding the product off into water, he allowed the valves to remain open for a period of time until he believed that all the product had vaporized and left the lines.  After following procedures for closing down the NH3 plant, bleeding off remaining NH3 and verifying that ammonia vapors were no longer coming out of the lines, the employee began maintenance repair work to remove the pump associated with the plant.  As the employee began to loosen the pump mounting bolts and remove the flange above the pump, he turned to grab a tool and ammonia vapor flashed out betwee

n the flange and the pump, coming into contact with the employee.  Employee proceeded to water spigot near the chemical mixing shed which is within 10 seconds travel time.  Employee used water to run continuously over his body and area of contact.  Employee was aided by a truck driver that was onsite but not assisting with maintenance.  The employee was taken to local emergency room where he was diagnosed with anhydrous ammonia injuries.  The most severe injury was an injury to the employee's right wrist and the employee was experiencing vision issues with his right eye.  





THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of the company  to immediately notify the responding fire department, and the appropriate LEPC/EMA to request that they respond to the emergency.  In the unlikely event that the responding fire department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at the location, the fire department with whom the responding fire department has a reciprocal agreement will be summoned.   This policy has been reviewed with the fire department and LEPC/EMA. 





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks.  In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise.  This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic.  Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires.  Th

is training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of the new hire.  The company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site.  Should the local fire department request assistance in the training of its employees on the properties and characteristics of anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates in their endeavors.
